docs.lead_paragraph: A synthetic pheromone-like chemical developed by a University of Cincinnati chemist has been found to disrupt the communication system of pine beetles, holding the promise of controlling the pest that annually destroys almost $1 billion worth of timber, the National Science Foundation has announced. The pheromone mimic is a form of peroxide that slowly undergoes a chemical transformation to the pheromone of the natural pine beetle. It was discovered by R. Marshall Wilson while studying laser-induced basic chemical reactions of pheromone-like compounds. Pheromones are chemicals secreted by animals that effect the behavior of others of the same species and usually act as sex attractants.
